Usage¶

Installation¶

To use genecomb, first install it using pip:

(.venv) $ pip install genecomb

Counting Bases¶

To count the bases in a genecomb sequence, you can use the GeneComb.base_counter function:

genecomb.GeneComb.base_counter(self)¶

This function returns count of all bases in a sequence as a dictionary Ex: ACGGGTAC -> {‘A’: 2, ‘C’: 2, ‘G’: 3, ‘T’: 1, ‘X’:0}

Returns:

The count of all bases as a dictionary

Return type:

dict

Calculating GC Content¶

The GC content of a sequence is the percentage of G’s and C’s in the nucleotide sequence. To calculate the GC content of a GeneComb sequence, you can use the GeneComb.gc_content function:

genecomb.GeneComb.gc_content(self)¶

This function returns the GC content of a sequence. Ex: If the sequence is 100 bases long and you have 20 C’s and 5 G’s, your GC content is 25%

Raises:

ZeroDivisionError – If sequence is empty

Returns:

the GC content of the GeneComb sequence

Return type:

float

Finding the number of Non-nucleotide Bases¶

It can be helpful to know the number of bases in a sequence that are not a valid nucleotide (A, C, G, T). You can quickly calculate this value using the GeneComb.non_nucleotide_counter function:

genecomb.GeneComb.non_nucleotide_counter(self)¶

This function parses a sequence and returns a list of the location of each non ACGT base and the length of unknown bases if they are consecutive Ex: ACNGGGNNNTAC -> [[2, 2],[6, 8]]

Returns:

dictionary in the form of {position: length}

Return type:

dict

Finding all palindromic subsequences¶

A palindromic sequence is a nucleic acid sequence in a double-stranded DNA or RNA molecule whereby reading in a certain direction (e.g. 5’ to 3’) on one strand is identical to the sequence in the same direction (e.g. 5’ to 3’) on the complementary strand [Source]. You can calculate all the palindromic sequences using the GeneComb.find_palindromes function:

genecomb.GeneComb.find_palindromes(self, removeOverlap=False)¶

This function parses the sequence and returns a list of palindromic nucleotide sequences within the seq.

Returns:

a list of all the palindromes. Each entry in the list is another with the start position at index 0 and the end position at index 1

Return type:

list[list[start, end]]

Transcribing a nucleotide sequence to RNA¶

Transcribing a DNA nucleotide sequence to RNA can be done using the GeneComb.get_rna_transcription function:

genecomb.GeneComb.get_rna_transcription(self)¶

Returns the transcribed sequence. Replaces all T’s with U’s

Returns:

The corresponding RNA sequence

Return type:

str

Translating a nucleotide sequence to protein bases¶

It can often be helpful to translate your nucleotide sequence into the corresponding protein sequence. This can be done using the GeneComb.translate_to_protein function:

genecomb.GeneComb.translate_to_protein(self, start=0, end=-1)¶

Transcribes to RNA, then Translates to Protein with Amino Acid Bases. It will carry out the tranlsation from start to end; or until one of the bases are not a valid rna nucleotide base (A, C, G, U).

Parameters:

  • start (int) – Optional param to designate the starting point of the translation. Defaults to 0.

  • end (int) – Option param to designate the ending point of the translation. Defaults to the end of the sequence.

Returns:

The protein sequence from start to end.

Return type:

str

Counting point mutations between two sequences¶

A point mutation is when two sequences that should be identical have a mismatch in a position. This can occur due to mutations in a sequence. To count the number of point mutations between two equal length sequences, you can use the genecomb.count_point_mutations function:

genecomb.count_point_mutations(gene_a, gene_b)¶

Counts the number of point mutations between two sequences of equal length

Parameters:

  • gene_a (str) – sequence A to be compared

  • gene_b (str) – sequence B to be compared

Raises:

genecomb.SequenceLengthMismatchException – If sequences are of different length

Returns:

The number of point mutations between two sequences of equal length

Return type:

int

Writing a GeneComb sequence to a FASTA file¶

You can write a GeneComb nucleotide sequence to a FASTA file with the GeneComb.write_to_fasta_file function:

genecomb.GeneComb.write_to_fasta_file(self, filepath, append=False, line_length=80)¶

Writes the sequence and header to a file in the FASTA format

Parameters:

  • filepath (str) – filepath for the file to write to

  • append (bool) – Option for appending to an existing file or overwriting. Defaults to false.

  • line_length (int) – Optional param for the length of the line when writing to file. Defaults to the FASTA standard of 80

Reading GeneComb sequences from a FASTA file¶

You can read a sequence (or multiple sequences) from a valid FASTA formatted file with the genecomb.read_fasta function:

genecomb.read_fasta(filepath)¶

Reads a .fasta file and returns a list of GeneComb objects. Each object corresponding to each sequence in the file

Parameters:

filepath (str) – filepath to read from

Returns:

Either a single GeneComb object with the sequence in the file, or a list of GeneComb sequences if more than one sequence can be found in the file.

Return type:

GeneComb or list[GeneComb]

genecomb
